channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: "我因耳鸣而失去的--我至今仍无法接受这一损失--是安静。"《1843》杂志探讨了为安静的消失而悲伤的感受
item.description:
“What I lost with tinnitus—and I still cannot quite reconcile myself to this loss—was silence.”

1843 magazine explores what it’s like to grieve for the disappearance of quiet https://t.co/ACpam8mfdQ

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 美国国会众议院通过了一项法案，迫使 TikTok 的所有者在六个月内出售该应用在美国的业务，或者关闭这些业务。如果 TikTok 被禁，美国本土的社交媒体公司将获得一笔意外之财 👇。
item.description:
The House of Representatives passed a bill that would compel TikTok’s owner either to sell the app’s American operations within six months or shut them down. If it gets banned, the country’s homegrown social-media companies would be in for a windfall https://t.co/jLZh1i7iXP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 在本周的 "Money Talks "节目中，@Alice_Ffulwood、@Birdyword 和 @TomLeeDevlin 将询问美国的牛市是否还能继续。收听播客： 🎧
item.description:
On this week’s “Money Talks”, @alice_fulwood, @Birdyword and @TomLeeDevlin ask whether America’s bull run can continue. Listen to the podcast: https://t.co/pzjeD4YibC 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 在人工智能工具可以用来扭曲或生成图像的时代，这种改变受到了前所未有的审查。什么时候照片修饰是有效的？ 👇
item.description:
In an age when AI tools can be used to distort or generate images, such changes are coming under more scrutiny than ever. When is photo retouching valid—and when does it go too far? https://t.co/CR52X4A4IR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 减少石油需求是可能的。但这并不容易。日益加剧的气候影响会不会在某个时候加快速度？还是选民会奖励那些放慢脚步的政治家？ 👇
item.description:
It’s possible to cut oil demand. But it’s not easy. Could intensifying climate impacts speed things up at some point? Or will voters reward politicians who slow things down? https://t.co/LusrAHsgEQ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 英格兰最珍贵的建筑都被 "列入 "具有特殊建筑或历史价值的名录。因此，未经许可对其进行改建属于刑事犯罪--但对许多人来说，这只是一种骚扰👇。
item.description:
England’s most prized buildings are “listed” as being of special architectural or historical interest. This makes it a criminal offence to alter them without permission—but for many people, that is a nuisance https://t.co/hu1r1Twkw0 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 货车专用快速充电器所需的电力远高于汽车，而且还需要大量停车空间。最快的充电器可以在几分钟内为汽车充好电，而货车则需要大约 90 分钟👇。
item.description:
Dedicated fast chargers for lorries require far more power than for cars, plus lots of parking space. The fastest chargers that can top up cars in a few minutes would take around 90 minutes for a lorry https://t.co/X5HK9TdSDH 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 世界不同地区人们思维方式的差异似乎正在扩大 👇
item.description:
The differences between how people think in different parts of the world seem to be widening https://t.co/7vX5ezPF0f 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: "罗伯特-莱特希泽在一篇特约撰文中写道："在一个假想的世界里，贸易完全自由和平衡，没有政府干预，人们可以想象关税是不必要的。"但在现实世界中，关税是有用的。
item.description:
“In a pretend world of completely free and balanced trade and no government interventions, one can imagine tariffs being unnecessary,” writes Robert Lighthizer in a guest essay. “In the real world, though, they can be useful” https://t.co/dSXUBDLzok

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 谁是海地军阀，他有多少支持者--为什么他的绰号是 "烤肉"？Getty Images
item.description:
Who is the Haitian warlord, how much support does he have—and why is his nickname “Barbecue”? We explain https://t.co/0y4bKjdbiW

Image: Getty Images pic.twitter.com/VLH4j0LGCl

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 马航 MH17 航班到底发生了什么👇？
item.description:
What really happened to Flight MH17 https://t.co/YHrMu8Ctgw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 美国的压裂和钻井技术改变了世界。其地缘政治影响不仅仅是削弱了俄罗斯的天然气武器👇。
item.description:
America’s fracking and drilling technologies have changed the world. The geopolitical implications go beyond the blunting of Russia’s gas weapon https://t.co/xVZssSioAL 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 去年推出的 WPL 可能会对女子板球比赛产生类似的影响。
item.description:
The men’s Indian Premier League has brought previously unfathomed sums of money into cricket.

The WPL, launched last year, could have a similar effect on the women’s game https://t.co/ZDXaW6XfII 🏏

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 在美国，很多人都想接受医疗培训。这个职业收入丰厚。但预计十年后，美国将短缺多达 124,000 名医生。这是怎么回事？ 👇
item.description:
Lots of people in America want to train as medics. The profession is lavishly paid. But in a decade the country is expected to have a shortage of up to 124,000 doctors. What is going on? https://t.co/AqqOF2BsGF 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 葡萄牙是近来欧洲经济最强劲的国家之一，这可能会让强硬右翼政党切加党的崛起令人惊讶。但这似乎表明，选民在投票时考虑的不仅仅是国内生产总值的增长👇。
item.description:
Portugal has had one of Europe’s strongest economies of late, which may make the rise of the hard-right Chega party surprising. But it seems to indicate that voters do not mark their ballots with mere GDP growth in mind https://t.co/R214g0gALh 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 大石油公司能逆向发展吗？该行业的一些人认为，将二氧化碳放回地下是其未来的关键👇。
item.description:
Can Big Oil run in reverse? Some of the industry sees putting carbon dioxide back in the ground as key to its future https://t.co/AjX7b4qomb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 11 月，美国人将选出他们的下一任总统。经济学人》正在追踪这场角逐。关注最新民调，阅读关于两位主要候选人的简短指南，并标记关键的选举日历日期👇。
item.description:
In November Americans will elect their next president. The Economist is tracking the contest. Follow the latest polls, read short guides on the two main candidates, and mark key electoral-calendar dates https://t.co/3xtMsL9iPm 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 2022 年，法国男女是欧洲身材最苗条的国家，只有 10% 的人被认为肥胖。查看地图，了解其他地区的肥胖率
item.description:
French women and men were the most slender in Europe in 2022—only 10% were considered obese. Explore our map to see the obesity rates in other regions https://t.co/C5C3qnlhQG

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: "经济学人阅读 "经常会推荐一些严肃主题的书籍。但今天，在 "智库 "节目中，我们将稍微放松一下，由 @CockettRichard 精选史上最有趣的书籍
item.description:
“The Economist Reads” often includes book recommendations on rather serious subjects. But today on “The Intelligence” we loosen up a little, with @CockettRichard’s picks of the funniest books ever written https://t.co/PjJIMeL3zm pic.twitter.com/OoYnDQfNhu

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 在一片反对派政治家或死亡、或入狱、或流亡的土地上，俄罗斯的选举似乎完全没有必要。但是，尽管选举结果不可避免，它对弗拉基米尔-普京的政权却至关重要。
item.description:
In a land where opposition politicians are dead, in prison or in exile, Russia’s election seems entirely unnecessary. But despite the inevitability of the result, it is crucially important for Vladimir Putin’s regime https://t.co/ppkeSQlGnv

Image: AFP pic.twitter.com/doLBFW0s1n

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 硅谷诞生了一些世界上最大的公司，但它却没有激发出多少长篇大论。为什么写一本关于科技世界的好书这么难？ 👇
item.description:
Silicon Valley has produced some of the world’s biggest companies, but it has not inspired many written accounts with a long shelf life. Why is it so hard to write a good book about the tech world? https://t.co/Hh5skcII4q 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 1973 年后的石油市场一直是供需增长速度之间的角力。在气候受限的世界里，这种增长必须终止。我们的特别报告探讨了这种转变的全球影响 👇。
item.description:
The post-1973 oil market has always been a tussle between the rate at which supply and demand have grown. In a climate-constrained world that growth must end.

Our special report considers the global impact of this shift https://t.co/G4oBLdV8wC 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 美墨会爆发贸易战吗？自唐纳德-特朗普就任总统以来，双边贸易逆差呈爆炸性增长👇。
item.description:
Could there be a US-Mexico trade war? The bilateral trade deficit has exploded since Donald Trump was president https://t.co/cnuHO6z2kB 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 最好的结果是 TikTok 能够存活下来。但这需要把这样一个重要的平台与中国这样一个操纵性强、意识形态色彩浓厚的国家的影响分离开来 👇
item.description:
The best outcome is one in which TikTok survives. But that requires separating such a prominent platform from the influence of a country as manipulative and ideological as China https://t.co/GfNCoDEGZm 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: "如果你想了解人工智能的起源，最好从其中的第二个词开始"。@alokjha 在 "巴贝奇 "节目中探讨了人脑结构如何启发了第一台 "会思考的机器"🎧。
item.description:
“If you want to understand the origins of artificial intelligence, it’s best to start with the second of those words.” @alokjha explores how the structure of the human brain inspired the first “thinking machines”, on “Babbage” https://t.co/a2xdnNZOTb 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 您能猜出世界上最昂贵的城市吗？ 👇
item.description:
Can you guess the world’s most expensive cities? https://t.co/eea0xvFA0y 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 石油的最终归宿将在海湾地区--海湾国家对此心知肚明。它们将如何利用这种力量？ 👇
item.description:
Oil’s endgame will be in the Gulf—and the Gulf states know it. How will they use this power? https://t.co/4FHuODy13N 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: Jimmy "Barbecue" Chérizier 是海地最著名的军阀。他的存在和声音就像滞留在波多黎各的总理的缺席和沉默一样。我们为您揭晓👇。
item.description:
Jimmy “Barbecue” Chérizier is Haiti’s most prominent warlord. He has been as present and vocal as the prime minister has been absent and silent, stranded in Puerto Rico.

Who is he? We explain https://t.co/p2fr3QGXVV 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: 在肯尼亚的一个角落，几乎每个人都参加了随机对照试验。有传言说，实验派发的现金会受到诅咒👇。
item.description:
In one corner of Kenya, virtually everyone has taken part in a randomised controlled trial. Rumours have spread that cash handouts from experiments are cursed https://t.co/Igksjhskvd 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 13, 2024

item.title: Jimmy "Barbecue" Chérizier 是海地最著名的军阀。他的存在和声音就像滞留在波多黎各的总理的缺席和沉默一样。我们为您揭晓👇。
item.description:
Jimmy “Barbecue” Chérizier is Haiti’s most prominent warlord. He has been as present and vocal as the prime minister has been absent and silent, stranded in Puerto Rico.

Who is he? We explain https://t.co/noBerIZnJj 👇
